Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Pain Education and Exercise Training in Primary Dysmenorrhea

Trial_Design.evidence: Nulligravid volunteers aged 18 years and older with PD were randomly assigned to PNE+ET or BPE+ET groups.

Participants.evidence: Nulligravid volunteers aged 18 years and older with PD were randomly assigned to PNE+ET or BPE+ET groups. The study was conducted at a physiotherapy and rehabilitation department.

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to PNE+ET or BPE+ET groups.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to compare the effects of pain neuroscience education (PNE) and biomedical pain education (BPE) combined with exercise training (ET) on primary dysmenorrhea (PD).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was menstrual pain intensity, measured over two menstrual cycles.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using an online tool with a block size of six, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 38 participants were randomised: 19 to PNE+ET and 19 to BPE+ET, between January 2022 and June 2022.

Number_Analysed.evidence: All participants were analysed using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: PNE+ET led to greater reductions in menstrual pain, central sensitization symptoms, and pain catastrophizing compared to BPE+ET (p < 0.05, Cohen’s d = 0.683–1.174).
